PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 1.45 p.m. , and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

To the Honourable The President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Covention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological, disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Harradine (from 43 citizens) and Macklin (from 128 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to the Australian Workers Union sponsored shearers' strike which is now in its seventh week. The issue is the use of a wide comb. Commissioner McKenzie of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission ruled that the comb may be used with the consent of owners and shearers. The union did not accept this and appealed to the Full Bench of the Commission, which upheld Commissioner McKenzie 's ruling. The Government's reaction is to support the union in yet another application to the Commission. Only yesterday, in north-western New South Wales, some 60 unionists vandalised a wool shed and threatened to burn it, boxed sheep, wasted expensive chemicals, assaulted a man and withdrew without an arrest being made, asserting that they would return. I understand that they have. I ask: Are there controls which are hampering the police in New South Wales in the performance of their duty? Does the Government intend to see the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's determinations upheld and law and order prevail? How does this relate to the Prime Minister's promotion of reconciliation? Will the Government ensure that this intolerable behaviour ceases and that appropriate arrests and charges are made? Will the Minister seek the Prime Minister's urgent attention and action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of questions have been asked by Senator Scott in relation to the wide comb shearing dispute. I will endeavour to answer the points that he made. First of all, it is correct that Commissioner McKenzie of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission made a decision regarding this matter in favour, if I can put it that way, of the use of wide comb shears. It is correct to say that since then there have been a number of instances of disputation and, in certain circumstances, violence, particularly between various groups of shearers, relating to the use of wide comb shears. On Friday, 29 April, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, after meeting with the parties-I do not state that categorically but he certainly arranged for senior officers of his department to meet with the parties-again referred the matter to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, not because it was felt that a different decision would be made about the use of wide combs but simply to try to get the parties together to discuss the dispute and to get some process of communication going between shearers, the relevant union and the employers involved.

ANSWER.PARA: The enforcement of the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is a different issue, of course, from the question which the honourable senator asked me about the role of the New South Wales police. I and this Government have no responsibility for the New South Wales police in respect of these matters. If acts of violence occurred they would be, presumably, reported to the nearest police station. Action may or may not be taken but that is not a matter upon which I can comment. Certainly no controls hamper the police as, I think, the question suggested.

This is a very difficult dispute. I said earlier that it is important to get some discussion of the issues around the table. A large number of New Zealand shearers who are used to using a wide comb are working in Australia. That has been a cause, I believe, of additional dispute. It is not the Government's view that this matter can be resolved, as it were, by punitive or police action. The Government is taking all possible steps to see that the disputation about the issue is resolved as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health say what the present regulations or practice are regarding the medical records of patients of a doctor who retires, closes the practice or dies? With the side effects of some drugs prescribed to patients becoming evident over the years after they have been taken, in some cases in the second or third generation, will the Minister consider ways by which a central register could be kept, on either microfilm or computer, of the patient's name and drugs prescribed to him or her? Does the Minister also consider this suggestion to be not only beneficial in providing the best health care and patient care but also in maintaining important statistics?

—It is my belief that at present patients' records in a doctor's practice, that doctor having died or retired, are handed to the person who succeeds him or her in that practice and not to anyone else. However, I will seek further details for Senator Elstob as to the regulations and laws applying in each State. Senator Elstob raised the very important issue in the second part of his question about the difficulties in this country and, in fact, in most other Western countries, in determining how we can best acquire access to the records of patients who are treated in private practice or by doctors of first contact so that we can carry out retrospective studies of people who have been taking various drugs. Because of our laws on privacy in this country there would be very great difficulties in having the medical records of individual patients put on microfilm for purposes such as this. There would probably be considerable resentment within the community about it. The doctor-patient relationship is considered important by both doctors and patients. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Health and get a more detailed reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. It follows recent correspondence with the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Did the Minister representing the Minister for Communications act unilaterally in announcing that he would write to the Chairman of the ABC without first seeking the agreement of the responsible Minister, the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy? Did he show the letter to the responsible Minister or to the Prime Minister before sending it, or did he discuss the issue with Mr Duffy beforehand? If not, is this not a serious breach of Cabinet ethics and practices?

—The last part of the question is a matter about which I do not propose to make a judgment. Senator Hill clearly has. The answer to the first part of the question is yes. The answer to each of the two other parts of the question is no.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. When was the previous Government informed of the projected Budget deficit for 1983-84? Secondly, did that Government spend any of the $1.5m that it set aside for publicising Government policies on the issue of the deficit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the previous Government was informed on the Tuesday prior to the election that the impending Budget deficit was over $9 billion, and that on the Friday immediately before the election it was told that the confirmed figure was nearly $10 billion. This, bear in mind, happened during the week in which the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, who is still the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, and the then Prime Minister were telling the nation that if the Labor Party were elected a catastrophic $10 billion deficit would be the result. Labor was elected and we are facing a prospective $10 billion deficit. Of course, the then Prime Minister and the then Treasurer, who is now the most discredited former Treasurer in Australian history, did not tell the truth to the Australian people.

ANSWER.PARA: During that week, when they had official advice from the Treasury that the deficit would be between $9 billion and $10 billion, they were telling the Australian people that the projected deficit under their Government's policies for next year would be $6 billion. I believe that is typical of the sort of disinformation and misinformation campaign which the Fraser Government, the most discredited former Government in Australian history, gave to the people throughout the seven years it was in power. Finally, that Government was recognised for what it was, that is, a government which was not only incompetent but also untruthful, and it suffered an ignominious defeat.

As for the second part of Senator Ray's question, as to whether any of the $1. 5m which was improperly set aside in the 1982-83 Budget for the purpose of financing a Government propaganda campaign for the election which the then Prime Minister intended to hold originally in September, then in November, and eventually did hold in March, was actually spent for the improper purpose for which it was originally appropriated, I do not know. I will check that out with the Treasurer and supply an answer as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Attorney-General share the concern of the Australian Democrats at last week's disclosures in the National Times which, if factual, indicate a serious lack of accountability of our secret service organisation, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, as well as improper actions by ASIO operatives? Is the Minister aware of comments on the AM program this morning by a lawyer to the effect that actions of ASIO operatives, if correctly described, may have amounted to treachery? In particular I draw attention to the way in which ASIO is reported to have collected information on Australian citizens and to have passed this information to other countries for use or potential use in the Australian political process? Will the Minister confirm the authenticity of these reports? Will he advise what urgent measures the Government intends to take to prevent a recurrence of such activities which jeopardise the civil liberties of Australian citizens in a way which allows them no opportunity of defending themselves or setting the record straight? What steps is he proposing to take to ensure that Australian secret service organisations are properly supervised and held accountable for their actions? Finally, what will be the policy of this Government as to whether journalists should be compelled to reveal the sources of their information in such matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matters in the National Times articles were of considerable concern to the Government. We have made that clear in the action we have subsequently taken. The authenticity of the articles as a whole, or of any particular part of them, is not a matter about which I believe it is proper to comment, certainly at this stage, for reasons that are quite familiar in dealing with security matters of this kind. In a sense an endless succession of questions as to the authenticity of each part of the document-while it may be doing no damage in one particular case-can result, by a process of elimination, in the authenticity of some remaining part being thus established. I think that is a well understood dilemma that all governments, however committed to freedom of information they may be, find themselves in. To the extent that there was any truth in the material, so far as the conduct of ASIO is concerned, it gives rise to quite profound concern by this Government as I imagine it would to any government. Of course that will lead to our taking appropriate action. I simply add in that respect that the matters referred to governing, in particular, the internal conduct of ASIO were, if true, matters relating to the situation within that organisation as it existed before the report of the Hope Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security and its aftermath action rather than purporting in any way to reflect the present day situation. I think the matter ought to be put in that perspective.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the accountability of ASIO I repeat for the record-as I have on numerous occasions both during the election campaign and previously-that this Government has a commitment to revising the governing legislation of ASIO in order to make for substantially greater accountability, both in terms of direct accountability to the government of the day and direct accountability in some significant respects to the Opposition of the day, regular judicial audits, better financial accountability through the Auditor-General and also more informative annual reports to the Parliament. It is also a matter of better mechanisms, under the Security Appeals Tribunal, to ensure that ASIO observes its charter when embarked upon surveillance and other operations purportedly within its sphere of action. All those matters are under very active review by the Government and were under active review prior to last week's matters.

As to the question of requiring journalists to disclose their sources, the Government is well appreciative of how sensitive a matter that is. No action that has been taken in the High Court of Australia has involved any obligation upon the journalists in question to disclose their sources to the Government. Whether or not there is a case for any change to the law as it presently stands- which, of course, gives no protection to journalists from disclosing their sources if they are put to that test in the court-is a matter for review taking into account what are obviously serious questions of principle on both sides of the argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, refers to the frequently stated intention of the Government to introduce a resource rent tax to replace the existing system of levies on mineral production and export. I ask the Minister: Why does the Government want to make this change to resource taxation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it might be advisable, for the benefit of the honourable members on the Opposition benches in particular, to attempt to explain to an unreceptive target group the concept of rent and why we propose to change the taxation system. In its original Ricardian agricultural sense, rent was the difference between the grain yield--
—Here we go.

—I suggest that the honourable senator pay attention. If he can absorb it he might be able to try to pass on his new-found knowledge to the troglodytes who run the Liberal Party of Australia in his State and who, in the space of two weeks, lost governments in Canberra and in Perth and lost two- thirds of the party's representation in the House of Representatives and one- third of its representation in the Senate.
—Order! I suggest the Minister direct his answer through the Chair .

—In its original sense, rent was the difference between the grain yield from the most unproductive land in cultivation and the higher yield from all other land. In a modern sense, it means any return to capital and labour in excess of that which is required to attract and hold the required level of resources in an industry. Rent accrues to all but the most marginal land and all but the most marginal mines. It accrues to other producers who are licensed in a restricted way and to other restricted entry occupations. The existence of rent in mines has long been implicitly acknowledged by the charging of royalties, which are usually levied on quantity production, on output. Sometimes those royalties are very high. The excise on Australian crude oil from the Bass Strait is a good example of a very high royalty-type payment.

ANSWER.PARA: The chief faults of royalty-type payments are, firstly, that they are applied equally, generally speaking, to both high cost producers and low cost producers. Therefore, the low cost producers are paying a royalty which is too low and which gives an insufficient return to society, which is the ultimate owner of the resource, and the high cost producers pay royalties or taxes which are too high.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The answer which is being given by the honourable senator is one which may well be of great value to the Senate in enlightenment but it is scarcely an answer to a question. It is a statement and explanation of the theory behind the resource rent approach to tax. I ask the Chair to require a reasonably prompt answer to a question. I am sure the Minister would be able to talk for an hour, as he told us in Question Time on a previous occasion. This is not the occasion on which to deal with a statement on the theory behind resource rent tax.

—I remind the Senate that Ministers are entitled to answer questions in the way in which they so choose but at the same time Ministers should take note of the fact that they are not entitled to debate matters at Question Time. I suggest that the Minister make his answer as succinct as possible.

—Mr President, in support of your ruling, the question of course explicitly sought an explanation of the reasons why the Government plans to make this change. I will not be very much longer with my answer, Mr President. I suggest that it would be in the long-term interests of the honourable senators opposite if, instead of screeching like a bunch of galahs, they actually applied whatever intellect they have to attempting to understand--
—Order! I ask the Minister to respond to the question asked by Senator Cook.

—The second principal fault of the types of taxes which are applied on rent now, and which have always been applied on the rent which exists in mines, is that such taxes impose a tax on marginal production and thereby induce social waste. Both of those undesirable faults in the existing system of taxation on mining enterprises are avoided if an appropriate tax directed at rent is introduced.
—I ask that the documents that the Minister was reading from be tabled.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, relates to the Minister's statement to the House of Representatives on 4 May 1983, and in particular to his announcement:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Ministry has not had sufficient time to give expression to the sentiments that we advanced in opposition about the use of the committee systems in the Parliament'.

In the light of the undertaking made by the Government upon its election that it would take the opportunity of completely revamping the way in which the policy committees of the House of Representatives, together with the joint committees, are structured and the firm commitments made by the Prime Minister on election night that this Government would reform the committee system so as to use the talents of all members of parliament, including members of the Opposition, I ask the Minister: Why has the Government not given greater priority to this task so that the House of Representatives will have established from the commencement of the Parliament a committee system of similar policy coverage and effectiveness as the Senate committee system? Is this inaction and the re-establishment of the old committees last week only another example of the Government's resolve to back away from its election undertakings and to avoid the scrutiny of its policies and legislation by effective all-party committees?

TALK.START.PARA: —A noble effort was in fact made by the Special Minister of State in conjunction with other Ministers and other members of parliament during the transition-to-government period and during this Government's first weeks in office to set in place some more rational committee system in the House of Representatives and, indeed, to integrate it better through the joint committee structure with the total committee system of the Parliament. There were, however , a number of different views, as the honourable senator would no doubt be able to imagine, on that issue by people who shared nonetheless the commitment to improving and streamlining the system. It might be said that there are a number of people who are profoundly conservative about the parliamentary committee system, not for reasons of desire to shelter behind inefficient procedures but simply because they feel comfortable in the existing structures. The reality of the matter was that it was very evident that a further process of consultation, including consultation with other parties, needed to take place if we were to be able to rationalise the committee structure in a way that was universally acceptable. The answer to the second part of the honourable senator's question is no.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Has that consultation with the other parties taken place since the election?

—My understanding is that it has. I will refer the honourable senator's question to the Minister in order to get some better detail about that. But certainly I know that it is his present intention over the winter recess period to develop a committee structure that is acceptable to everyone.

—I direct to the Minister representing the Treasurer a question relating to the Foreign Investment Review Board's refusal to allow Korean participation in the Jackson-Moonie oil pipeline. Is it correct, as the Courier- Mail of 5 May reported was stated by the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke- Petersen, that the Koreans took the initial risks in relation to the project and after that others became interested? Or is it correct, as the National Times of 6 to 12 May reported was implied by the General Manager of CSR Ltd, Mr Bryan Kelman, that the Korean group, ICC, became involved in the Jackson-Moonie pipeline due to pressure brought to bear on the other partners by the Queensland Premier?

—The situation, as I understand it, is that the Australian partners had fully arranged the finance for the project and did not want any foreign partner or equity. They were then leaned upon, I think it would be fair to say, by the Queensland Government to accept the Korean partner, ICC. Given the normal free enterprise rhetoric of the Queensland Government, that seems to be a rather extraordinary decision to interfere in the satisfactory arrangements which had already been made by Australian businesses, against the will of Australian businesses. It also raises the question of the extraordinary sympathy which that Korean firm, ICC, has been able to attract from the present Government of Queensland and the former Government of Western Australia. That firm was let a tender for the construction of one-third of the Dampier to Wagerup pipeline, which was not, I understand, put out to tender. That firm had no previous experience anywhere in the world in constructing that sort of pipeline. I could speculate about the special relationship which that Korean firm appears to have had with one present and one former conservative State government as to what considerations may have been made in order to induce both of those governments to act in a way which favoured the interests of that particular firm against the interests and desires of Australian firms. I could speculate about that matter but I do not propose to do so at this stage.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Why did his letter to the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission give details only of the complaint about ABC management action in relation to AM reporter Helen O'Neil and not cover the subsequently released approaches by Mr Hawke to Professor Kramer on other matters? Was this omission because the Leader realised that, in revealing the other matters, he and Mr Hawke would be exposed for their blatant attempts to stop the ABC running a particular story? Will ministerial interference in the independence of the national broadcasting authority be a continuing feature of this Government's administration? Further, since the Prime Minister indicated publicly some knowledge of the contents of Senator Button's letter, did he know of the convenient errors in it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of parts to Senator Collard's question, but let me start once again, if I can, from the beginning. I am asked first of all: Why did I not in the letter to Professor Kramer cover a wide range of issues which subsequently became public knowledge? The answer is simply that when I was asked a question in the Senate about this matter I said that Professor Kramer had not, in my view, always acted without fear or favour in respect of the public affairs programs of the ABC. In my view to establish that point it was sufficient to itemise one matter in the letter which I sent to Professor Kramer.
—You were wrong.

—That is a matter for judgment but in my view it was sufficient for me to itemise one point in the letter to Professor Kramer to establish my view. But, of course, subsequent to this question being asked and answered in the Senate, Professor Kramer took up a cry which was commenced by Senator Baume that first of all I had used parliamentary privilege in some way to attack or defame her--
—So you have.

—I am prepared to debate that with the honourable senator. The second point of the allegation was that I had been defamatory in what I had said and the third point was that she did not understand what I was talking about. Last week the issues were firstly whether I had used parliamentary privilege to defame Professor Kramer and, secondly, whether she knew what I was referring to when I gave that answer in the Senate. Let me say in regard to two of the three matters, which are matters of public discussion, that if anybody else wants to say outside the House what was said on the ABC program on 4 February this year let that person do it and see how he or she gets on. They were the two principal matters discussed with Professor Kramer as was the Helen O'Neil incident in the same context. Those matters became the subject of debate last week. They are matters of dispute between Professor Kramer and me as to a set of facts. My recollection has been challenged on the question. Professor Kramer has now given quite explicit details of the three complaints allegedly made by Mr Hawke. Let us look at what Professor Kramer said when she was making the allegation that I had used the privileges of parliament to defame her in some way. Let us see what she said about that question when appearing on the Nationwide program on 4 May. Geraldine Doogue asked:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . have you any idea what Senator Button meant when he suggested that you hadn't always acted without fear or favour.
The answer was:

I have absolutely no idea and I am astonished that he should have made such an accusation within Parliament where he has privilege and I hope that he will come outside Parliament and explain what he means.
I might interpolate that I had no hesitation in doing that and I have never hesitated from criticising the Commission of the ABC on particular issues. Geraldine Doogue went on to ask:
No ideas about, maybe problems that occurred during the campaign between the ABC and the Labour Party. There are stories that there were some complaints.
Dame Leonie Kramer replied:

Well, my understanding is that both major parties felt that our election coverage had been very fair and very reasonable and there has been no complaint of any kind from either party since that coverage.
Dame Leonie Kramer was again asked: 'Are there any stories that have been referred to you about the Four Corners program?' The answer was:
. . . none at all. No.
Geraldine Doogue asked:
No stories referred up that you may have expressed dissatisfaction with that could have filtered back to the Labour Party in any shape or form.
Dame Leonie Kramer replied:
Nothing of any kind . . . I am absolutely mystified . . .

That is the context of the discussion about people's recollection of what took place between Professor Kramer and me and Professor Kramer and the Prime Minister during the context of the election campaign. The answer to the question of whether interference will be a continuing endeavour of this Government is, of course, no. The legislation which will be introduced into this Parliament by this Government in the next few weeks will provide a complaints procedure which will obviate the necessity for anything of that kind in the future and will ensure--

TALK.START.PARA: —I can imagine Mr Hawke ringing the complaints section.
—Order! Senator Button has the floor.

—It will mean, for example, that if the Australian Broadcasting Commission, as the national independent broadcasting service, makes statements which are untrue and defamatory of members of this Parliament, those complaints will be investigated by an independent officer and, if necessary, the ABC would be requested to retract. That is an appropriate procedure which is identical almost to the procedures of the British Broadcasting Corporation. That will be introduced in the legislation which will shortly be coming before Parliament. So the answer to the final part of Senator Collard's question is that this Government is committed to the independence of the ABC and to procedures which will ensure greater independence than it has ever had in the past.

—Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of reports in the newspapers claiming that many people who had suffered loss of or damage to their homes as a result of the Ash Wednesday bushfires have experienced difficulty in obtaining an equitable settlement from their insurers? Is he aware, in particular, of claims that in many cases insurers have held that householders were under-insured and have limited their settlement to an amount that is insufficient to cover damage incurred and that in other cases insurers have held that householders were over-insured and have limited their settlement to amounts less than the sum insured? Is the Minister, as the Minister responsible for the administration of the Defence Service Homes Insurance Scheme, satisfied that all policy holders under that scheme who suffered loss or damage in the tragic circumstances of the Ash Wednesday bushfires have been adequately and equitably compensated and that their claims have been dealt with without delay or inconvenience?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Primmer, who comes from Victoria and represents a rural constituency, would be well aware that there are great problems about the bushfires on the outskirts of our major cities in Victoria and South Australia. I thank him for the question because there is no doubt that, as a result of those disastrous fires that took place in February, not only were there personal tragedies but also a number of financial tragedies affecting great numbers of our citizens. It is true that considerable public criticism is being levelled at insurance companies to the extent that large numbers of claims have not been satisfactorily dealt with by the companies concerned. I can assure the Senate that that is not the case with respect to the Defence Service Homes Corporation. Perhaps the Senate would be interested to know that both Mr Justice Kirby, the Chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission, and the Victorian Minister of Consumer Affairs have called for an urgent review of insurance forms as they relate to fire insurance problems. They have called for a standardised form so that the sorts of problems faced by the citizens who lost their homes in those disastrous fires in Victoria and South Australia can be minimised in future. We are talking of claims involving something in excess of $200m. I am led to believe that the Ministers responsible for consumer affairs from the various States will be meeting during May for the purpose of establishing some common ground in these areas so that the sorts of financial tragedies that occurred subsequent to the fires will be obviated in future.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as defence service homes are concerned, I am advised that there is no particular problem with respect to the claims that have been submitted-some 102 in total. Twenty-seven homes in Victoria and two in South Australia were totally destroyed. At this moment only five such claims have not yet been finalised. Of course, under our scheme-the Defence Service Homes Insurance Scheme-only the actual building is insured, whereas some of the conflicts that exist in other areas deal with the contents of homes. There are, of course, differences between the insurance companies and the claimants. I assure the Senate that those claims that are still in dispute will be satisfactorily resolved because the intention of the Defence Service Homes Insurance Scheme is to meet as far as practicable the claims of those who unfortunately lost their possessions during those fires.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate agree with descriptions of his charges against the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission as being frivolous, vexatious and trivial in the extreme or does he still seriously ask us to accept his view put here last week that Professor Kramer had not always acted without fear or favour? Does the factual error in his letter to the Chairman concerning the circumstances of the Helen O'Neil interview reflect the confused and intemperate nature of his attack? Will he now , in view of widespread condemnation of his actions, publicly apologise to Professor Kramer?

—I have indicated my view about Professor Kramer on a number of occasions. My view is that she is a very distinguished Australian and talented scholar. That view, however, does not prevent my having differences of opinion with her about particular matters, and I would be very sorry if it did. I do not accept the description of the charges that I made as being frivolous, vexatious and trivial. In relation to the second portion of the question, I simply say that I refer to my answer on Wednesday, 4 May.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I remind the Minister that the previous Government did incalculable damage to the Greek community and to racial harmony in Australia when it instituted terrifying dawn raids and cancelled hundreds of invalid pensions almost five years ago. As all the pensioners were admitted to be innocent when the Liberal-National Party Government withdrew from the case nearly a year ago, what does this Government intend to do about holding an inquiry into the circumstances of the arrests, the stopping of the pensions and benefits and other relevant matters associated with this outrageous incident?

—The so-called social security conspiracy case was a matter with which I was associated in this Parliament from the time it started. It caused great concern at the time not only to the Greek community but also to the then Opposition and all sensible Australians. Many aspects of the case caused us concern at that time and have continued to do so. I refer to the nature of the raids which were conducted on the first day; the manner in which the charges were laid; the conduct of the case and the fact that after costing in excess of $10m the charges had to be withdrawn; the magistrate's comments concerning the evidence given by two of the principal witnesses in the case; the matter of compensation to those who were charged, and who had the case hanging over their heads for so long; and the problems faced by those Greek and Australian citizens who went overseas and who in some cases had to return to get justice. In light of these matters I have had discussions with the Attorney-General about what should be done. The Senate will know that before the election we announced that, if elected, we would conduct an inquiry. We will conduct such an inquiry. The nature of the inquiry is a matter for discussion at the moment. The Attorney- General will announce it to the Senate as soon as it has been decided.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the widespread reports that Mr John Menadue is considered likely to be appointed Managing Director of the new Australian Broadcasting Corporation, I ask: Has the Government -or any of its Ministers-taken any steps in furtherance of Mr Menadue's candidature for this position? Has Cabinet-or any group of Ministers-discussed with likely nominees to the board of the Corporation the person it wishes to see appointed to the position of Managing Director? If so, does he agree that such action is totally inappropriate, given that the selection of a Managing Director is a matter not for the Government but for the yet to be appointed board?

—There has been no discussion of any kind about the likely appointment which the board, when it is appointed, might make to the position of Managing Director of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The legislation is not yet through the Parliament. Of course, the legislation provides-I take it that Senator Teague has seen a copy of it-that the board shall make the appointment. I believe that that is a refreshing innovation. The honourable senator asked whether the Cabinet or any group of Ministers had discussed the position of likely nominees to the board. The normal answer to that question, correctly, should be that I am not in a position to disclose whether Cabinet has discussed that matter. I would normally give such an answer. But the answer, in all frankness, is that Cabinet has not considered that matter. It will do so at an appropriate time. I am unable to say whether any group of Ministers-Senator Teague may believe that two, three or four would constitute a conspiracy-has discussed the question of possible appointments to the board. I make it clear that I have discussed the matter with one colleague.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of Senator Button's denial of ministerial canvassing on behalf of Mr Menadue, how does he explain the extensive and apparently authoritative media reporting on this subject? Will he deny that there is any substance to the rumors?

—There has certainly been no authoritative media reporting; none at all. In fact, the media reporting on this issue has been so authoritative that many journalists have considered Mr Menadue, by way of rumor, as an appropriate chairman of the board, which indicates a total state of confusion. I repeat that there has been no authoritative reporting on that issue at all.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEVELOPING COUNTRIES: TRADE AND TARIFF CONCESSIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Is it a fact that countries such as Korea, Singapore, Yugoslavia, Taiwan and Brazil are still afforded developing country status, entitling them to special trade and tariff concessions? Is it also a fact that it is the highly technical manufacturing industries of these countries which are presently threatening Australia's own manufacturing industries? Given that there has not been a review of this since 1973, can the Minister inform the Senate whether a review of the list of countries receiving developing country preferences in trade arrangements will be forthcoming in the near future?

—The matters set out in the honourable senator's question are correct, except that I am advised that the last review took place in 1976, not 1973; but that does not seem to me to be a very material fact insofar as the question is concerned. Currently in my Department a review is taking place of the Australian system of tariff preferences for developing countries. I believe that that review ought to be completed, possibly by the end of this month but certainly by early next month. I appreciate Senator Richardson's concern about imports from some of the so-called developing countries, countries which may in a cultural and educational sense not be as developed as Australia but which, certainly in terms of modern technology, are probably well ahead.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. In the conduct of the Australian Broadcasting Commission as a statutory corporation is not the general management and conduct of staff the responsibility of the senior staff officers and the General Manager? Does the Minister suggest that all reprimands of staff members by their senior officers should be made known to the Commission and should be subject to reversal by the commissioners? Under what circumstances should the commissioners interfere with the decisions of management regarding the conduct of staff?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In effect, Senator Reid is asking me for an opinion on this matter.
—It is a proper question.

—If I can have the assistance of the Senate, the functions of the Commission are spelt out in the Australian Broadcasting Commission legislation and the Commision is responsible for the statutory corporation which it administers. In the Australian Broadcasting Commission it has been a generally accepted view that decisions about program matters should be left to the program staff. Unfortunately, that is not a course which has always been followed. To cite an example which is close to my mind, last week the current Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission said that her function was to defend the staff of the ABC. On another occasion she said that it was not her function to interfere with the staff of the ABC. By that she meant the program making staff, I assume, because she said that in the context of program makers. That is a totally contrary position to the position which she, as Chairman of the ABC, adopted in October 1982 when there was a complaint from Sir Charles Court about the content of a program. On that occasion Chairman of the ABC certainly did not interfere with the staff, she did not even consult them; she apologised on their behalf for the program without any reference to the program-making staff of the ABC.

ANSWER.PARA: I raise that example because it is, of course, relevant in dealing with this somewhat confused issue of the role of the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I would have thought that if the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission takes upon herself or himself the task of receiving complaints and undertaking to respond to them that would inevitably involve, at some stage, some interference with staff, as indeed did the incident about Sir Charles Court's complaint.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the incident with Mr Hawke and you.
—And the incident with Mr Hawke and me, yes, of course.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is it a fact that Liberal Prime Ministers have shamelessly manipulated the Australian electoral system over the years to call Federal elections at times of their own choosing rather than allowing the Parliament to run its full term of three years? Has the new Labor Government any proposal which might change the situation to the great benefit of electors who are sick and tired of being forced to the polls and to the great benefit of the nation in the planning of both the public and the private sectors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will come as no surprise to either the honourable senator or the Senate to know that it is my view, and that of the Australian Labor Party and, indeed, that of most Australians, that there has been shameful manipulation of election dates by Prime Ministers, particularly Tory Prime Ministers, in recent times. It is very much the view of most Australians that good government would be better served in this country by a system of fixed-term parliaments. Accordingly, the Government has today announced a proposed referendum on that subject for 20 August this year, just before Parliament resumes for the Budget session. That issue will be accompanied by three other measures, interchange of powers, advisory opinions and the removal of outmoded provisions from the Constitution, the common theme in all four matters to be put to the people being an improvement in the machinery of government in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no question of any attempted accretion of power by the Commonwealth at the expense of the States in any of these referendum proposals. Two of them at least, interchange of powers and outmoded provisions, have been the subject of unanimous resolutions at successive meetings of the Australian Constitutional Convention. The matter of advisory opinions has been the subject of strong majority resolutions at that Convention. The matter of fixed-term parliaments was, of course, the subject of some controversy at the most recent Convention but it enjoys strong majority support as is evident from such opinion polls as have been taken. It certainly enjoys strong support from within the Liberal parties in at least three States of this nation. It certainly enjoys strong support within the ranks of the Liberal Party in Canberra as was demonstrated during the debate on the Bill relating to the issue last year when a number of honourable senators from the other side of the chamber crossed the floor.

I believe that this is a matter on which genuine consensus is both desirable and necessary and capable also of being achieved. I hope that a dog-in-the- manger attitude towards this proposal is not adopted by our opponents, either when the matters are being debated, as they must be, in the Senate and eventually when they are, as I hope they will be, put to referendum on 20 August . Finally, I add that the rationale of the fixed-term parliaments proposal, going back to the substance of Senator Tate's question, is good government in the sense, not least, of the capacity of both government and the private sector to plan their business with some efficiency and confidence in the predictability of what will occur. One of the greatest debilitating factors in the operation of the Australian economy in recent years-any businessman will say this on the subject if asked-has been the profound uncertainty and unpredictability that has governed the performance of government at thd national level. This is something that will be not only welcomed but also actively sought by the business community for the reason that it appreciates that it is very much in the interests of good government in this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to an answer which he gave earlier in Question Time to Senator Hill in which he advised the Senate that he acted unilaterally in announcing that he would write to the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and indicated that he did not show the letter to the responsible Minister or to the Prime Minister before sending it. He indicated also that he did not discuss the issue with Mr Duffy beforehand. I again ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Did he discuss the letter which he sent to Dame Leonie Kramer with Mr Duffy before it was sent to Dame Leonie?

—On the assumption that that is the same question which I was previously asked, my recollection is that I certainly did not show the letter to Mr Duffy before I sent it. I certainly did not show it to him. I am unable to say whether I discussed the incident described in the letter with Mr Duffy at some time or another in the last two months, but I certainly did not show him the letter.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question related to whether there was any discussion with Mr Duffy about the fact of the letter or its contents before the letter was sent.

—There was certainly no discussion about the contents of the letter before it was sent. On the afternoon of the 4th of this month I issued a Press statement announcing that I intended to write to Professor Kramer about those matters. Whether in the normal course of events Mr Duffy was passed a copy of that Press statement I am unable to say.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to an article in this morning's Canberra Times in which a Mr Tom Brennan claims he was given the run around by the Department of Social Security when he applied for copies of the Department's manuals under the Freedom of Information Act. What views does the Minister hold about the unwillingness of his Department to release the manuals? Is it true that the same officer who reviewed the decision also conducted the internal review required by the Freedom of Information Act? What action will the Minister take to ensure that manuals requested under the Freedom of Information Act are made available?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When in Opposition the Australian Labor Party and I at all times supported public access to the manuals and published guidelines of the Department of Social Security. We held that view then, we hold it now and we will continue to hold it. When I became the Minister for Social Security I learnt that my Department was fighting an application by Mr Waterford to have access in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to the old manuals. After consultation with the Attorney-General it was decided that the Department would withdraw from those hearings as our view then was that access to those manuals was justified. The proviso was given that those manuals were at that stage out of date and contained some inaccuracies. We wished to make it clear to Mr Waterford and Mr Brennan, who was associated with a similar application, that those manuals were inaccurate and out of date.

ANSWER.PARA: It was normal procedure in the Department up until then that in such a new field as freedom of information the most senior officers of the Department would be involved in both the early decision making and its later reviews. I express the view that the Government and I are opposed in principle to review officers, in circumstances like that and that of the review of invalid pensions, being people who took a part in the making of the original decisions. In that regard, if Mr Waterford's report is accurate-I am checking on whether it is accurate-we would not like that situation to arise, although when it did arise the Department had some difficulties because the most senior people in the Department were making the decisions. Such officers are, of course, limited in number and finding a review officer meant going to that same level of officers in the Department.

In relation to the general implementation of the Freedom of Information Act as it affects the Department of Social Security, 80 per cent of requests received have been for access to personal documents. Of the 736 requests received, 530 have been decided upon, all within the statutory time limit of 60 days. I am sure that the Department will continue to do that. The Department is aware that there is a new Government, and that it has views on freedom of information which it expressed in Opposition and continues to express in Government. I am sure that the Department will conform to those views and to both the spirit and the word of the legislation which is in place and which, I understand, will be modified in the near future.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Prior to the double dissolution, the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts was inquiring into the development and implementation of a co-ordinated language policy for Australia. This inquiry is wide in scope. Its objective is to examine the need for, and nature of, a comprehensive national language policy for Australia. Central to the inquiry is an examination of the role of, and need for, English and other languages in Australia, including Aboriginal languages and the language needs of the deaf and disabled. The problems of the illiterate, the need for translating and interpreting services and the teaching of languages are covered by the terms of reference.

SPEECH.PARA: This inquiry has generated considerable interest and expectations. These have been reflected in conferences organised to discuss the issues, the large number of submissions and correspondence received, as well as the enthusiasm and efforts of the many interested parties. At a private meeting last Thursday, 5 May, 1983, the new Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts decided to continue with the inquiry.

During the previous Parliament, the Committee conducted a number of preliminary public and private hearings. It had just begun its main program of public hearings when the Parliament was dissolved. The Committee is now planning further public hearings. These will be held in Canberra on 20 and 30 May, in Adelaide and Perth next month, and in the Northern Territory, Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne in July. The Committee plans to report to the Senate in the Autumn session next year.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRADE AND COMMERCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-During the Thirty-second Parliament the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce commenced an inquiry into the Australian export coal industry. Since the election in March, a number of developments have occurred in the coal industry which have had a direct bearing on the state of our inquiry. In particular, on 30 March 1983 the Australian Coal Consultative Council was established to provide a new forum for continued discussion and review of the industry's economic and structural problems. This 27-member Council, with representatives from the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Queensland governments, coal boards, unions and mining companies, held its inaugural meeting in Canberra on Friday, 28 April 1983. The formation of this Consultative Council is fully endorsed by all members of my Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: With the establishment of this Council, my Committee now believes that it would be inappropriate to continue our inquiry. We feel that it is only fair to allow this representative Council time to settle in and come to terms with a number of extremely fluid and sensitive industrial and economic problems that presently confront the industry. Had we decided to continue with our inquiry it would have overlapped, in many areas, with the work that is to be undertaken by the Council . The Committee is therefore suspending its inquiry until the more immediate problems of the industry have been addressed by the ACCC. Once this has occurred the Committee will then reconsider its terms of reference of the inquiry in the light of the industry situation then prevailing.

In conclusion, I would like to thank all the organisations and people that have already participated in the inquiry and trust that they will co-operate fully with the Australian Coal Consultative Council during its crucial deliberations.

—Mr President, on the point of order, Senator Ryan is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment; I am simply the Minister representing the Minister for the purpose of this Bill.
